summary:
Clemens Hosman runs a Prevention Consultancy & Innovation Agency and is emeritus Professor of Mental Health Promotion and Prevention (Maastricht University & Radboud University Nijmegen, Netherlands.  He is Visiting Professor at Universities of Zagreb, Lisbon and Geneva. His research is targeted at youth mental health promotion, prevention of depression, preventing intergenerational transmission of mental disorders, poverty-related health, community interventions, program & policy development, effect studies, effect & impact management, integrative policies &  collective impact, 'smart cluster' approaches, and innovation.  

He is involved in prevention and mental health promotion since 1969 and played a crucial role in the development of this field in the Netherlands and Europe. He occupied many international positions, e.g. chair European WHO Task Force on MH Promotion & Prevention, board member US Society for Prevention Research, Chair Global Consortium for Prevention/Promotion in Mental Health. He chaired world conferences in prevention, among others on "Intergenerational Mental Health",  Bazel 2016. He was co-project leader of EU prevention projects and is international prevention consultant to NGO’s and governmental agencies, e.g. WHO and European Community that Care Network. He is senior consultant of Dutch cities on prevention, public health & social policy, youth health policy and poverty programmes. He chaired National Committees on professional guideline development in mental health care and primary mental health care. 

He received the 2002 International Collaborative Prevention Research Award of the US Society of Prevention Research; the 2001 Friend of the Early Career Preventionist Award for his life-long work in educating new generations of prevention experts; in 2005 the honorary membership of the Dutch Society for Prevention and Health Promotion. He was awarded by World Federation for Mental Health by being invited to give the George Albee Memorial Lecture 2009 on the future of prevention.

profile_positions.description:
The development of the IM-PACT Model and IM-PACT management model was part of the CIKEO consortium project  on  evidence-based preventive parenting interventions. This project was initiatied by the National Health Research and Development Fund (ZonMw) in The Netherlands and is a consortium of Erasmus University Rotterdam, Leiden University, Verwey-Jonker Institute and Hosman Prevention Innovation Consultancy.   The reasearch aim of this consortium was to evaluate the empirical knowledge about evidence-based preventive parenting interventions and their core working ingredients.  Within this project I run together with the Jonker Verwey Institute the study on the core elements, factors, and processes  that drive the public and  social impact of these preventive interventions. This was motivated by the finding that such eviden-based preventive interventions have low reach and impact on targeted populations of parents, families and children.  
This research efforts resulted in a new and comprehensive IM-PACT model and IM-PACT Management model  providing a theoretical and strategic map to municipalities, local organizations and citizen groups to work collaboratively at improving and maximizing the common public and social impact of local  youth policies, programmes and interventions.

Attached you find our presentation on the IM-PACT model offered during the international online conference of ZonMw titled  Building on Effectiveness Research: Results and Lessons Learned from Research into Core Elements of Youth Interventions, 26 November 2020.

profile_positions.description:
I am working as senior scientific advisor of the City of Rotterdam for evidence-based youth prevention policy, health promotion and development policy and poverty policy.  This also includes consultancy to neighborhood-based projects such as 'Promising neighborhoods' , innovative poverty projects (e.g. House of the Future linked to energiy transition) and Voorgoed Agency Rotterdam (social impact investment).

Collaboratively with city policymakers, we have developed am integrative multilevel model of evidence-based factors of health, mental health and social development in children, adolescents and young adults.  Currently, we are expanding this model to a life span model covering all age groups from - 9 months, birth to elderly.  Related to this model we are building a database of empirical knowledge on the causal influence and long term effects of the incuded factors, based on information from international meta-analyses, review studies and large scale polpulation studies.

Next, in collaboration  with dr. Harrie Jonkman (Verwey-Jonker institute) we developed the IM-PACT Model and  IM-PACT Management model to support municipalities, local organizations, professionals and citizen groups in maximizing the impact of their public health and social efforts to improve the health and developments of citizens. Based on multidisciplinary studies and our own long term participating observations we have integrated in this model a wide range of factors, processes and components influencing  the public and social impact of available evidence-based interventions. Linking these interventions or their working elements with bottom-up initiatives is supported.   (Hosman & Jonkman 2020, werken aan publieke en maatschappelijke impact. Verwey-Jonker instituut).

profile_positions.description: The Gulbankin Foundation hosted the Global Project on Social Determinants and Mental Health, leaded by Prof. Benadetto Saraceno (former WHO Director of Mental Health, Prof. Jose Miguel de Almeida (Medical Faculty, University of Lisbon) and Prof. Sir Malcom Marmot (Institute of Social Equity, UK). The Global Project is focused among others on understanding the impact of economic recessions and poverty on mental health and its implications for public mental health and social policies. As prevention experts I adviced the Project Committee on options for mitigating the impact of economic recessions ans poverty on mental health using evidence-based prevention strategies and interventions and knowledge from prevention science. This has been summarized in my keynote presentation at the Global Conference on Socioenonomic Crisis and Mental Health, 24-25 of November 2016 in Lisbon (see attached PowerPoint presentation)
